newsitem.title: FINLAND: PROTOS SEES MARKKA GOING EASILY BELOW 2.90/MARK.
newsitem.headline: PROTOS SEES MARKKA GOING EASILY BELOW 2.90/MARK.

text.p: If the German mark continued to weaken, the Finnish markka could easily strengthen to below 2.90 per mark, brokerage Davy Protos wrote in a weekly report received on Tuesday.

"If the dollar joins the strengthening trend against the DEM, the process could start to accelerate by itself," Protos said, adding the German mark was still some 10 percent overvalued in trade weighted terms. The overvaluation started in 1992 when Europe's currency markets were in turmoil, it said.
"If the correction in the DEM continues, the DEM/FIM, currently 2.99, could easily go below 2.90," Protos said.
And if the markka firmed, expectations of a new tender rate cut by the Bank of Finland would increase, it said.
This scenario meant that "the short end of the yield curve is well bid," Protos said.
The longer end of the yield curve should draw support from solid fundamentals, it said, referring to low inflation and the strengthening of the markka.
Protos said it did not recommend selling the 2004 and 2006 benchmarks because a tightening of Finnish monetary policy was "not in the pipeline during the next six months."
